name: NPR
text: He made the Fugees go ooh-la-la and turned Ini Kamoze into a hotstepper. Producer @SaLaAMReMi also used classic samples to sonically reinvent @nas and Amy Winehouse.  On The Formula, he shares his recipe for pulling the best out of both songwriters. https://t.co/fzi5sCeKma https://t.co/mGEwg0PUiz

name: NPR
text:
President Trump briefly wore a face mask during his visit to a Ford plant, away from cameras.
 
"I wore one on in this back area. I didn't want to give the press the pleasure of seeing it," Trump said.  https://t.co/0mOVk46R06

name: NPR
text: What do Quakers have to do with the history of the price tag? Turns out, a lot more than you knew. A @planetmoney investigation. https://t.co/ForjfvRgp8

name: NPR
text: Since the pandemic started, 38.6 million Americans have filed for unemployment claims — using an unemployment insurance system established in 1935 to serve a very different population.  https://t.co/Io2XuliAHX

name: NPR
text: Roughly one-third of summer internships have been canceled — but it's not too late to get that resume booster. Here's a guide to finding online and remote internship programs still accepting applications: https://t.co/fv1N6F0CNE

name: NPR
text: Universal Orlando and Legoland have local approval to reopen in June — with safety plans including temperature checks, face masks and limited capacity.  https://t.co/PrXhDHObqU

name: NPR
text:
New York City officials say roughly 1 in 4 residents may be going hungry. Starting next week, they plan to deliver over a million free meals a day. 
https://t.co/Zb0Mz9yJ50

name: NPR
text:
A quarter of employees at a Tyson poultry processing facility in Wilkesboro, N.C., have tested positive for the coronavirus. 

A majority of those who had the virus didn't show any symptoms, the company says.
https://t.co/pgsTRBfvhX

name: NPR
text: The CDC is mixing up the results of two different kinds of tests in its tally of coronavirus testing — raising concerns among scientists that it could be creating a false picture of the pandemic as states reopen.   https://t.co/CBKTxfxBWp

name: NPR
text:
Washington state officials launched an online portal to report non-essential businesses operating despite an order that they close.

But some people have received threats after filing reports and having their information released by the state. (@KUOW) https://t.co/DrMAy2gYAo

name: NPR
text: Rachel Portman — the first woman composer to win an Oscar for best original score — is releasing her first album of music not written for a movie, TV or stage production. https://t.co/MA4ZzB8aNL

name: NPR
text:
The Indigo Girls are more than just a band.

Over the 35 years of their group's history, their music has given insight into what female friendship — lesbian friendship in particular — can offer to our divided worlds. https://t.co/6W0GuZgCFu

name: NPR
text:
Looking for peace and quiet? Or dreaming of spending time with loved ones on the beach, mountains or forests? What about owning a farm and wading through grasslands?

You should try Minecraft, our critic writes. https://t.co/SdQkeEgri7

name: NPR
text:
Bartolomé Perez has worked at McDonald's for 30 years. Now, he's fighting for worker safety. 

"We have always been essential," Perez says. "It's just that the company strategizes a narrative about us workers, saying that ... we are replaceable." https://t.co/DCw9YeQsLK

name: NPR
text: New findings suggest air conditioners can blow around infected droplets hanging in the air -- with enough air movement, your nose can pull in large particles. Unless systems consistently pump in outside air, there's a risk. @hereandnow https://t.co/00efJdOaw0

name: NPR
text: There is refreshing anger in Porochista Khakpour’s essay collection, “Brown Album." Anger at erasure, misogyny and racism — and how at times, she too has been complicit. But these essays might be too short for analysis on class and race, our critic writes. https://t.co/mjG62uKh1m

name: NPR
text:
New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is encouraging businesses to consider a 4-day work week as a way to spur domestic travel in the wake of the country's coronavirus lockdown.
https://t.co/TAe5Lu05eu

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking coronavirus restrictions in every state — and the steps officials are taking to reopen their communities.

West: https://t.co/xk0iKqqht2
Midwest: https://t.co/LKunNveZyY
South: https://t.co/SQ2157VKkQ
Northeast: https://t.co/2cEsSBV6fU

https://t.co/BiHRPByRPc

name: NPR
text:
Macy's says its first-quarter losses might reach $1.1 billion. It's the latest example of a widening gap in retail between big sales of "essential stores" that remained open versus "non-essential stores" that had to close.
 https://t.co/Uec2sGRq8M

name: NPR
text:
Researchers say performing two coronavirus antibody tests could reduce false-positive errors. The method would look for two different antibodies, targeting two different regions of the virus.
https://t.co/fVPoMz5NKA

name: NPR
text:
The White House says it might extend "opportunity zone" tax breaks as a way to help struggling neighborhoods after the pandemic. But critics say the program has benefited wealthy investors more than local residents.
https://t.co/kWxnFO5KkL

name: NPR
text:
Food banks are getting a lot of attention and donations right now. Yet many people who run them say there's a more important — and efficient — way to fight hunger: Give people money to buy groceries.

That's what SNAP does. 
https://t.co/7rpqtoxdYM

name: NPR
text:
The battle for the presidency is now largely being waged online — where the Trump campaign has been building its presence since 2015.

The Biden campaign, on the other hand, has a digital presence that's admittedly still in development. https://t.co/J2Bo0xcWRu

name: NPR
text: A passenger jet carrying around 100 people crashed in a residential section of Karachi — Pakistan's most populated city. The mayor says there were no survivors on board. https://t.co/M6lfV2gaon

name: NPR
text:
Bright green balls of moss called "glacier mice" move around glaciers in a coordinated, herdlike fashion that researchers can not yet explain.

"They really do look like little mammals ... running around on the glacier," one wildlife biologist says.
https://t.co/EOmoDQDoz5

name: NPR
text: @NPR Other local officials said there were at least two survivors. https://t.co/ga5mGMH6Jt

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Anthony Fauci said his team is now compiling full details from the Phase 1 trial of a coronavirus vaccine under development by Moderna. 

"Having looked at the data myself, it is really quite promising," he said. https://t.co/bHYDhQC5Nh

name: NPR
text:
Happy Friday! Join us and @jamesreinhart for a LIVE conversation about how you can still thrift shop during the pandemic. Ask your questions! 

Supported by @crowdstrike
 https://t.co/PIw6ul2ipO

name: NPR
text:
Despite finalizing just one conviction in nearly two decades, the U.S. prison and military court at Guantánamo has cost taxpayers over $6 billion. 

Now the pandemic has brought proceedings to a halt.

Critics say this is a chance to shut it down for good.
https://t.co/lLDdvD9WkC

name: NPR
text:
Since the beginning of the pandemic, conspiracy theories about COVID-19 have increased. 

But conspiracy theories themselves are nothing new; they're a fundamental part of American life. 

From @ThroughlineNPR: how these theories helped to create the U.S. https://t.co/rxOR0DLvyA https://t.co/gWTPp002fJ

name: NPR
text:
Dagestan's health minister recently said the republic had just 29 COVID-19 deaths — but 657 deaths from "community-acquired pneumonia." 

"It long ago became clear the official statistics have no basis in reality," one resident tells NPR. https://t.co/S7zjBJplWr

name: NPR
text:
William "Roddie" Bryan — the man who filmed the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery  — has said he was a witness. 

"I can tell you that if we believed he was a witness we wouldn't have arrested him," said the director of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation. https://t.co/YZEyfdOJgm

name: NPR
text:
RT @hereandnow: We're LIVE!  

Join host @TonyaMosley's Facebook Live chat with Netflix's "Hollywood" writer/director/producer @janetmock 🎥

Watch here: https://t.co/5k0RDZvpul https://t.co/i5k6tpi5BP

name: NPR
text:
Few can belt the way that Lady Gaga can — and Ariana Grande is one of them. 
https://t.co/beKP5Z81JC

name: NPR
text:
Patients who recover from the coronavirus and test positive again do not appear to be contagious, a study from the South Korean Center for Disease Control finds. 
https://t.co/NFtN4E9Z1m

name: NPR
text: China is scrapping its annual economic growth targets for the first time since 1990. Instead, leaders will focus on reducing unemployment and poverty alleviation amid the pandemic. https://t.co/JmpSbPCqOV
